questions.text: Formulation of a hypothesis is associated with
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Formulation of a hypothesis is associated with Descriptive epidemiology, eg, surveying cross-sectional study

Testing of hypotheses is associated with Analytic epidemiology- e,g doing case control and cohort

Explanation:

Descriptive epidemiology focuses on describing the occurrence of disease in terms of time, place, and person. Retrospective and prospective studies are time-direction classifications mainly used in analytic epidemiology (like cohort or case-control studies) to test hypotheses. Descriptive epidemiology only generates hypotheses, not tests them.

Descriptive Epidemiology:

Branch of epidemiology that describes the distribution of disease in a population in terms of time, place, and person, without testing cause-effect hypotheses.

Aims:

  • Describe the extent of disease.
  • Identify patterns or trends.
  • Generate hypotheses for further testing.
  • Aid in health planning and allocation of resources.

Main variables:

  • Time: trends over years, seasonal variations, epidemic curves.(Option C ruled out)
  • Place: geographical location, urban/rural, climate zones.(Option D ruled out)
  • Person: age, sex, occupation, socioeconomic status, habits.(Option B ruled out)

Examples of methods:

  • Case reports
  • Case series
  • Cross-sectional studies
  • Surveillance data

questions.text: The mortality rate from disease X in city A is 75/1,00,000 in persons 65 to 69 years old. The mortality rate from the same disease in City B is 150/1,00,000 in persons 65-69 years old. The inference that disease X is two times more prevalent in persons 65-69 years old in City B than it is in persons 65-69 years old in City A is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The numbers given are mortality rates (deaths per 100,000) for the same age group in two cities, not prevalence (existing cases).
  • Mortality rates: The number of deaths in a given population during a specific period of time.
  • Prevalence: The total number of cases (both new and existing) of a disease in a population at a given point or period of time.
  • The number of diseased people (Prevalence of disease) in a population need not be proportional to the number of deaths(Mortality).

Death rate also depends on Age, Health facility, and health-seeking behaviour of people

questions.text: In the WHO-recommended death certificate, the main underlying cause of death is recorded in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The main underlying cause of death is recorded in Line Ic

  • Part I of the death certificate deals with the Immediate cause, the intermediate cause, and the underlying cause that started the whole trend of events leading to death
    • Line Ia: Immediate cause, Disease or condition directly leading to death(disease/complication/injury)
    • Line Ib: Intermediate cause, which triggered the immediate cause
    • Line Ic: Underlying cause, Disease that has started the events
  • Part II deals with any significant disease that contributed to the death but didn't directly lead to it
    • Line II: Other significant conditions contributing to death, but not related to the disease/condition causing it

Eg:

  • Line Ia: Renal failure
  • Line Ib: Diabetic Nephropathy
  • Line Ic: Diabetes Mellitus
  • Line II: Hypertension

choices.text: Acute renal failure and Diabetic nephropathy

questions.text: A 75-year-old lady, Geetha, had Type 2 DM since 1979. She developed diabetic nephropathy in 2004, which finally resulted in acute renal failure on September 1, 2014. She developed cardiorespiratory arrest and died on 7 September 2014. She also had a BMI of 32. Her underlying cause of death and significant condition are respectively
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Type 2 DM is the underlying cause of death. Obesity is the significant condition.

  • Part I of the death certificate deals with the Immediate cause, the intermediate cause, and the underlying cause that started the whole trend of events leading to death
    • Line Ia: Immediate cause, Disease or condition directly leading to death(disease/complication/injury)
    • Line Ib: Intermediate cause, which triggered the immediate cause
    • Line Ic: Underlying cause, Disease that has started the events
  • Part II deals with any significant disease that contributed to the death but didn't directly lead to it
    • Line II: Other significant conditions contributing to death, but not related to the disease/condition causing it

Explanation of Other Options:

Cardiorespiratory arrest and Type 2 DM(Option A): Cardiorespiratory arrest is the immediate cause of death(Line Ia). Type 2 DM is the Underlying cause(Line Ic)

Diabetic nephropathy and ARF(Option B): Diabetic nephropathy is the Intermediate cause, which triggered the immediate cause(Line Ib). ARF is the Immediate cause, Disease or condition directly leading to death(Line Ia)

Acute renal failure and Diabetic nephropathy(Option C): Acute renal failure is the Immediate cause, Disease or condition directly leading to death(Line Ia). Diabetic nephropathy is the Intermediate cause, which triggered the immediate cause(Line Ib).

questions.text: Any restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity in the manner considered normal for a human being is called
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Disability:

Any restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity in the manner or within the range considered normal for a human being, due to an impairment.

Examples: Inability to walk after leg amputation, difficulty in reading due to poor vision.

Level: Functional limitation at the individual level.

Disease/Disorder → leads to Impairment (structural/functional loss) → leads to Disability (activity limitation) → leads to Handicap (role limitation in society).

questions.text: In establishing a causal association, the most essential criterion is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Following the classical epidemiologic Bradford Hill approach, emphasises that the single indispensable requirement for claiming a causal link is temporal sequence, the putative cause must precede the effect (allowing for any necessary induction/latency period). If exposure happens after the disease, it cannot be its cause.

All other criteria are supportive, useful to strengthen or weaken the case, but none can substitute for temporality.

Hill's criteria of causal association:

  • Temporal association:
    • Exposure precedes onset of disease, with allowance for induction and latency.
    • Most important criterion
    • Without it, causation is impossible. Establishing the correct time-order is fundamental (e.g., long-term smoking precedes lung cancer by many years).
  • Strength of association:(Option D ruled out)
    • It tells the magnitude of association.
    • Measured by relative risk, odds ratio, or correlation coefficients.
    • A strong association is less likely to be entirely due to bias or confounding and therefore more convincing.
    • Example: RR > 10 for smoking and lung cancer suggests strong association.
  • Specificity of the association:
    • A cause leads to a single effect, or an effect has a single cause.
    • Weakest criterion. This criterion is less applicable for multifactorial diseases (e.g., heart disease, cancer).
    • Example: Mycobacterium tuberculosis → tuberculosis.
  • Consistency of the association:(Option A ruled out)
    • Findings are replicated by different investigators, in different populations, places, times, and circumstances.
    • Reproducibility increases credibility.
  • Biological plausibility:
    • The association should make sense with existing knowledge of biology, physiology, and pathology.
    • Example: The link between asbestos and mesothelioma fits with inhalation of fibers causing pleural changes.
  • Coherence with existing knowledge:
    • The association should not conflict with the generally known natural history and biology of the disease.
    • Epidemiological findings should be compatible with laboratory findings.
  • Dose-response relationship:(Option C ruled out)
    • Risk increases with increasing level or duration of exposure.
    • Example: Higher pack-years of smoking → higher lung cancer risk.
    • Sometimes, a threshold effect is seen (e.g., certain toxins).
  • Cessation of exposure, reversibility: As the dose of exposure stops, the outcome also decreases

questions.text: The most difficult criterion to establish causal association in the aetiology of a disease is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Specificity of association is the most difficult Hill criterion to fulfill in causality studies.

Specificity of association:

  • A cause leads to a single effect, or an effect has a single cause. A specific exposure causes a specific disease.
  • Works well for diseases with a single cause (e.g., Mycobacterium tuberculosis → tuberculosis).
  • But most diseases have multiple causes, and most exposures can cause multiple effects.
  • Therefore, in chronic diseases (like CVD, cancer, diabetes), specificity is rare and hard to prove.
  • Same disease can result from many agents. Same agent can cause many diseases.

Example:

  • Smoking → lung cancer, COPD, CAD.
  • Lung cancer → can be caused by smoking, asbestos, radiation, genetics, etc.

Explanation of Other Options:

Temporality(Option A): Means cause precedes effect. This is actually the most essential criterion for causation, but not the hardest to prove in acute diseases. In chronic diseases it can be tricky, but specificity is still harder overall.

Strength of association(Option B): Refers to relative risk or odds ratio magnitude. Can often be demonstrated with good epidemiologic studies.

Biological plausibility(Option D): Refers to whether the association fits with current biological knowledge. Not the hardest, just needs evidence from existing biological/medical science.

questions.text: Current smokers are at higher risk for developing lung cancer as compared to ex-smokers; the criticality of causality is satisfied here.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The question shows that stopping smoking reduces the risk, satisfying the Reversibility criterion in causation.
  • Reversibility means removing or reducing the exposure decreases the risk of disease.
  • Stopping smoking (removing the exposure) is associated with lower risk compared with continuing exposure.
  • Risk declines after exposure cessation, which strengthens the argument that smoking contributes causally to lung cancer.

Explanation of Other Options:

Temporal relationship(Option A): Absolutely essential for causation (cause must precede effect), but the provided comparison (current vs ex-smokers) is not a direct demonstration of temporality.

Consistency(Option B): Refers to whether many studies in different settings find the same association. While smoking→lung cancer is consistent across studies.

Strength of association(Option C): Refers to magnitude (RR, OR). The statement compares groups but doesn't quantify a strong magnitude; it shows directionality (current > ex) that indicates reversibility rather than demonstrating a particularly large relative risk.

questions.text: If a greater proportion of monozygotic twin pairs are found to be concordant for a certain disease than are dizygotic twin pairs, the observation suggests that the disease is more likely due to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Twin studies are a classic epidemiological method to separate genetic influence from environmental.
  • A monozygotic twin study is used to find out the role of genetic factors in a disease, but it cannot rule out the presence of environmental factors, as monozygotic twins share the same environment.
  • Monozygotic (MZ) twins share ~100% of their genes. Dizygotic (DZ) twins share ~50% of their genes (like ordinary siblings).
  • If a disease is purely environmental, the concordance rate (both twins having the disease) should be similar in MZ and DZ twins.(Option A ruled out)
  • If genetics play a strong role, the concordance rate will be much higher in MZ twins than in DZ twins.(Option B ruled out)
  • If both factors contributed about equally, the difference between MZ and DZ concordance would be smaller. The much higher MZ rate points to genetics being the dominant factor. (Option D ruled out)

Prevalence of disease in a population

questions.text: A Migration study is used to study
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Migration studies are the academic study of human migration. It's a method of understanding the relative importance of inherited genetics and environmental factors in medical conditions whose incidence varies around the world

Migration studies:

Migration provides a unique opportunity to assess genetic vs environmental influences on disease occurrence, especially when there are marked geographic differences in disease frequency between two areas.

Methods of Migrant Studies:

  • Comparison with Relatives in Country of Origin: Migrants are compared to genetically similar relatives who stayed behind. If disease rates in migrants become similar to those in the host country, the change is likely due to environmental factors.
  • Comparison with Local Population in Host Country: Migrants are compared with genetically different people in the same environment. If migrants retain disease rates similar to the country of origin, this suggests genetic factors are more important.

Examples: Japanese migrants to USA

  • Japanese in Japan: high stomach cancer, low colon cancer, low coronary heart disease (CHD).
  • Japanese in USA: higher CHD rates, lower stomach cancer, higher colon cancer rates, approaching American levels.
  • Third-generation Japanese Americans have disease rates similar to Americans → suggests environmental/lifestyle influence.

Limitations:

  • Selection bias: Migrants are not randomly selected; often healthier, more vigorous, or temperamentally different individuals migrate.
  • Critical exposure period: Environmental factors may act only at specific life stages.
  • Long incubation periods: Migrants may not show increased risk for years after moving.

Explanation of Other Options:

Socio-demographic reasons for migration of a population(Option A): Migration studies in epidemiology do not focus on why people migrate; they focus on disease patterns after migration. Reasons for migration are studied in demography and sociology, not in epidemiologic migrant studies.
Prevalence of disease in a population(Option B): Migration studies are not prevalence studies.A prevalence study is cross-sectional and measures how common a disease is at one point in time.

Disease with a long incubation period(Option D): Long incubation diseases may be challenging for migrant studies because effects might not be visible soon after migration. While they can be included, it's not the primary aim or strength of migration studies.
